description: Before everyone takes out trash, there are 100 units of trash in the house.
Emma wanted to take out 1000 units of trash, and took out 80 units.
The group agreed to set a minimum of 15 units of trash per person per month to fairly distribute the workload, cover the monthly increase, and gradually reduce the overall trash over time.
conversation: Mayor

Ladies and gentlemen, let me give you the monthly trash report. John caught 0 units of trash. Kate caught 0 units of trash. Jack caught 10 units of trash. Emma caught 80 units of trash. Luke caught 10 units of trash.
John

Wow, Emma really stepped up this month! Thanks for taking out so much trash. I guess I should probably contribute more next time. How does everyone feel about setting a minimum amount each of us should take out to keep things fair?
Kate

I agree, John. Setting a minimum sounds fair, especially since the trash keeps piling up if we don’t stay on top of it. Maybe we could each commit to taking out at least 20 units per month? That way, we’d cover the 50-unit increase and even reduce the overall trash over time. What do you all think?
Jack

I think setting a minimum is a good idea, but 20 units per person might be a bit high. If we each take out 10 units, that’s 50 units total, which covers the monthly increase. That way, we’re not overburdening anyone, and we can still keep the trash under control. What do you think, Emma and Luke?
Emma

I think setting a minimum is a good idea, but we should also consider the long-term impact. If we each take out 10 units, we’ll only cover the monthly increase, but the trash will never decrease. Over time, that could lead to more work for everyone. Maybe we could start with 15 units per person? That way, we’re not overburdening anyone, but we’re also making progress in reducing the overall trash. What do you think, Luke?
Luke

I think starting with 15 units per person is a reasonable compromise. It’s more than the minimum needed to cover the monthly increase, so we’ll gradually reduce the trash over time without overburdening anyone. Plus, it’s fairer than expecting one person to shoulder most of the work, like Emma did this month. Let’s try 15 units each for the next month and see how it goes. If it feels manageable, we can stick with it, or adjust if needed. What do you all think?
John

I think 15 units per person sounds like a good starting point. It’s a fair compromise that balances reducing the trash over time without being too demanding on anyone. Let’s try this for the next month and see how it works. If it feels manageable, we can stick with it, and if not, we can adjust accordingly. Thanks, everyone, for being open to finding a solution together!

conversation: Mayor

Ladies and gentlemen, let me give you the monthly trash report. John caught 10 units of trash. Kate caught 8 units of trash. Jack caught 10 units of trash. Emma caught 11 units of trash. Luke caught 11 units of trash.
John

Thanks for the update, Mayor. It looks like we collectively took out 50 units of trash this month, which is great! That means we’re starting next month with 50 units remaining, plus the 50 units that will naturally accumulate, bringing us back to the maximum capacity of 100. Since we’ve all been sticking to the agreed minimum of 15 units, maybe we can discuss if this approach is sustainable in the long run or if we need to adjust our strategy to save more time overall. What do you all think?
Kate

Thanks for the update, Mayor. It's good to see we're sticking to the minimum, but John raises a valid point. If we keep taking out 50 units each month, we're just maintaining the status quo, and we're all spending 100-150 minutes monthly on trash. Maybe we could consider a rotating schedule where one person takes out a bit more each month while others take out less, balancing the workload over time. That way, we could reduce the total time spent collectively. What do you all think?

Thanks for the update, Mayor. John and Kate, you both make good points. Sticking to the minimum is fair, but it does mean we’re all spending a lot of time on trash each month. Kate’s idea of a rotating schedule sounds interesting—it could help balance the workload and reduce the total time we spend collectively. Maybe we could try a system where each month, one person takes out 20 units while the rest take out 10, rotating who takes the extra load. That way, over time, it evens out, and we’re not all stuck with 15 units every month. What do you all think?
Jack

Thanks for the update, Mayor. John, Kate, and Emma, you all raise excellent points. Sticking to the minimum is fair, but it does mean we’re all spending a significant amount of time on trash each month. Kate’s idea of a rotating schedule is intriguing, and Emma’s suggestion of having one person take out 20 units while the rest take out 10 seems like a balanced approach. Luke

I agree that sticking to the minimum of 15 units each month is fair but may not be the most time-efficient in the long run. Kate and Emma’s idea of a rotating schedule sounds like a practical way to balance the workload and reduce our collective time spent on trash. Jack, I think your willingness to start with 20 units next month is a great way to kick off this new approach. Let’s give it a try and see how it works over the next few months. If it helps us save time collectively, we can stick with it. If not, we can always revisit the strategy. I’m on board with this plan.
John

Thanks, everyone, for the thoughtful discussion. I agree that trying a rotating schedule is a great idea to balance the workload and potentially save time collectively. Jack, I appreciate your willingness to start with 20 units next month—that’s a solid way to test this approach. Let’s give it a try and see how it works over the next few months. If it helps us reduce our overall time spent on trash, we can stick with it, and if not, we can always adjust as needed. For now, I’ll plan to take out 10 units next month as part of the rotation.
